   Michael Chippendale
   stated on April 12, 2013 in a debate on WPRI's "Newsmakers program":
   If an individual is determined "to commit suicide, the availability of a
   gun is not a factor" because they will find a way.

The availability of a gun
   is not what makes a person commit suicide, mental illness is.

We were interested in Chippendale's assertion that the availability of a
   gun is not a factor in whether a person commits suicide because suicidal
   people just find other ways to end their lives, a phenomenon researchers
   refer to as "substitution."

Some people
   determined to kill themselves are locked into that decision and will find
   another method if a gun isn't handy.
